Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Preoperative Inorganic Nitrate in Cardiac Surgery

Participants.evidence: Participants were 82 patients aged 18-80 years undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting with cardiopulmonary bypass. Exclusion criteria included pregnancy, re-do surgery, and significant organ disease.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomised in blocks of four to receive either oral sodium nitrate (700 mg×2) or placebo (NaCl) before surgery.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated whether preoperative inorganic nitrate administration could reduce troponin T release and other organ injury biomarkers in cardiac surgery patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was troponin T release over 72 hours postoperatively.

Blinding.evidence: all participants, clinicians, and outcome assessors were blinded

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 95 patients were randomised, with 42 in the placebo group and 40 in the nitrate group completing the study.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 42 in the placebo group and 40 in the nitrate group completing the study.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 72-hour troponin T release did not differ significantly between groups (p=0.19).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported.

Funding.evidence: The study was funded by institutional grants.
